'comments': 8, 'created_at': '2017-09-18T04:12:16Z', 'updated_at': '2022-02-10T16:00:34Z', 'closed_at': '2019-02-04T20:23:13Z', 'author_association': 'MEMBER', 'active_lock_reason': None, 'body': 'ServiceClient creates a new root HttpClientHandler (WebRequestHandler or HttpClientHandler) when it is not passed into the constructor. This handler is never disposed.

This leads to the following behaviors when multiple serviceClients are created:
 - A connection leaks and is not disposed until the 120second timeout.
 - A this is limited to 200 connections by default, this leads to socket starvation and requests failing to be processed

See https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-net/issues/2225 and https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-net/issues/1234 for examples of this issue.

The standard recommendation is to use a singleton ServiceClient (although the guidance should more likely be to use a singleton HttpClientHandler), but in some environments (such as Azure Functions for small functions) this is not possible / practical.

Recommendation:
 - ServiceClient should store a flag saying whether it created / owns the HttpClientHandler
 - ServiceClient should dispose that as part of dispose

It is possible that this will be a breaking change for some users who are relying on this not being disposed / extracting the client. This could be resolved by a flag (similar to the one implemented in https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-net/pull/3547).', 'reactions': {'url':
